captions.text:
These books are all about this ring. How it's
found and [spoiler alert] how it's destroyed.

While Tolkien built the largest and most consistent
fictional universe he sure didn't mind being

vague at times -- so if you finished the story
and then thought: wait, what can this ring

do and where did it come from? This is your
video.

First thing first: The One Ring is not the
only ring -- it's Lord of the Ring*s*, after
all -- and that lord is Sauron.

Long before this story starts, Sauron disguised
himself and came to the elves to work with

their master craftsman Celebrimbor to forge
the rings of power. Together they made 16

-- called the lesser rings, then Celebrimbor
took Sauron's formula and made three on his

own that turned out more powerful than the
original 16.

Why make rings based on the suggestion of
a stranger whose resume has a millennia-long

gap? Because he promised the rings would fix
the Elves biggest problem: this world is winding

down. The amount of big and awesome and magic
decreases as a function of time here.

For elves, magic *immortal* creatures, this
is bad news. Sauron said the rings would preserve

what their wearers cared about most. That's
why the Elven kingdoms are so fantastical

compared to the rest of the world -- their
rings have preserved them

Unlike the famous poem implies, the elves
made all the rings for themselves intending

exactly 0 to get into the hands of men or
dwarves, whom the elves think are stinky -- so

obviously something went wrong. Which brings
us back to The One Ring to rule them all.

Sauron's chief ability's is to dominate the
minds of others -- that's partly why he's

able to control such large armies -- and he
secretly made the The One Ring as a kind of

lens to focus this power -- his formula for
ring construction, unknown to Celebrimbor,

also made the wearers of the nineteen rings
more vulnerable.

Basically: The One Ring buffs his psy attack
and the other rings debuf psy defense.

Plan A was to control a bunch of high-level
elves. But when he put The One ring on, the

elves' base-level stats allowed them to resist
and take off their rings just in time.

Sauron captured Celebrimbor and tortured him
until he gave up the 16 lesser rings -- but

he died before revealing who was protecting
the three most powerful ones.

So Sauron now had 16 mind-controlling rings
and had to turn to plan B: dwarves.

Sauron manipulated sevens rings into the hands
of the dwarven kings but that didn't work

well either -- Dwarves are a kind of clockwork
creature Sauron found impossible to control.

But the rings weren't super helpful for dwarves
either who loved treasure above all else so

the rings grew their hordes large enough to
attract dragons who ate the dwarves and their
precious rings.

Finally, in the hands of men, ever the corruptible
species, the rings worked as expected: Sauron

controlled their minds. And, as mortals, they
valued their lives the most, which the rings

stretched for 1,000s of years. Stretched so
thin the men turn into invisible wraiths.

Anyway, these domination plans don't go unnoticed,
there�s a big war -- Sauron is defeated
and fades and The One Ring is lost.

But the One ring is tricksy. It has a mind
of its own and wants to get back to Sauron,
which brings us back to its powers:

First: the ring tempts everyone (Well, almost
everyone) with promises that, yes this little

ring can be a mighty weapon or a tool to reshape
the world, and gosh, don't you just look like

the best guy to use it? Let's go vanquish
the powerful-demigod who lives over there
to get started, shall we. Hmmm?

This is why the Hobbits made great ring bearers:
because they're pretty happy with the way

things are and don't aspire to greatness.
Of course, there's Gollum who started out

as a hobbit, but all things considered he
held out pretty well for a couple hundred

years. Set the ring on the desk of most men
and they wouldn't be able to finish their

coffee before heading to Mordor to rule the
world and do it right this time.

It's worth considering that The One Ring's
promises are just lies -- that no one could

*really* overthrow Sauron with it -- The Ring
only wants to trick its wearer to get found
which brings us to...
Invisibility.

Which outside the minds of characters, is
the only, tangible power the ring displays

for everyone else -- Invisibility seems great
-- but while you're hiding from that troll

you shine like a beacon in the unseen world.
Where the, also invisible ring wraiths, can
easily spot you.
In summary:

The One Ring
a) Turns you invisible in the most unhelpful

manner
b) Is probably filled with lies, because
c) It's part of Sauron and works for him.

He's so connected to it, that its destruction
ends him for good. But the formula also intertwines

The One Ring with all the rest. And so when
it fails, so do they.

This is why the elves are *so somber*. Victory
over Sauron also means that the rings won't

preserve their kingdoms anymore -- and all
will diminish. These books are the end of

the age of magic and the beginning of the
age of men.

(Link to LoTR wallpapers at the end)
Hello Internet, if you like LOTR and this

artwork, I�ve made a wallpaper pack of every
piece of art available over at Patreon. They�re

all available in 4K so you can use them on
anything from a huge screen all the way down

to your iPhone. Click here to go check them
out.

title: The One Ring Explained. (Lord of the Rings Mythology Part 2)

comments.text:
“Three Rings for the Elven-kings under the sky,
Seven for the Dwarf-lords in halls of stone,
Nine for Mortal Men, doomed to die,
One for the Dark Lord on his dark throne
In the Land of Mordor where the Shadows lie.
One Ring to rule them all, One Ring to find them,
One Ring to bring them all and in the darkness bind them.
In the Land of Mordor where the Shadows lie.” 

― J.R.R. Tolkien, The Lord of the Rings﻿

rings inside some massive super-secured magical underground vault, and 
Sauron can't do jack s*** with the one ring since he has no one to control

Man, LOTR characters really over-think everything. First this, then the

seriously, Gandalf literally says with his DYING WORDS (at least I don't 
think he knew he would live, doesn't matter anyway) "fly you fools!", what 
did you think he meant? go trip on acid? Damn...﻿
comments.author: Tom Gross

comments.text:
+Tom Gross Oh no... I wrote a lengthy response and it dissappeared ... :(

Well... again...

I'll give you some explanations that are "inside the story" and then an 
"outside the story" explanation...

Inside the story you can think that Frodo needed to develop strong enough 
willpower to continue his quest. Also it is implied that the Eagles are 
servants of Manwë, one of the Angelic rulers of Valinor, and that Manwë 
does not want to meddle too directly into the events of Middle-earth 
(earlier direct interventions had caused quite a bit of suffering) and that 
the Ring is something that the peoples of Middle-earth must solve 
themselves in order to grow up. I find certain aspects of this explanation 
satisfying for me but I can relate to people who are not convinced.

Outside the story explanation goes like this: Tolkien was very anti-modern 
person in some aspects. He vehemently opposed something that can only be 
described as "the Machine". With this concept he did not only mean the 
technology of his time, but human endeavor to find alternative solutions to 
problems that could be solved better by development of human person and 
virtues. Let me attempt to explain... :

Technology/science and "magic" are quite resent concepts and if we apply 
these concepts to Renaissance period or Early Modern period we are quite 
anachronistic. You can consider the famous saying: "any technology 
sufficiently developed will be indistinguishable from magic". Heyday of 
many "magical" practices (horoscopes, alchemy, Faustian necromancy) 
occurred in the same time as the emergence of modern science. They both 
work in the same principle: we can make apparatuses through which we can 
affect physical world and dominate it. Only way we now can distinguish 
"magic" from "technology" is by hindsight... what did work is science and 
what did not work we label as magic or superstition.

The crux of the issue is that we want to find ways to dominate this world 
and other persons. It can happen for example through science or magic. 
Tolkien considered travelling by foot to be superior for inner human 
development and for the growth of that person in virtues when compared to 

travelling by train for example. That might be one reason why the book has 
so much walking. Humans want to have "power" so they develop means by which 
they shorten the distance between desire and its fulfillment, between 
beginning and the end, so that it is finally brought to nought. 

When it comes to travelling, it can happen by technology (train) or by 
"magic" (flying carpet, teleportation etc), when the natural for human 
would be to travel by foot. This also brings us more fulfillment. Train and 
teleportation in this context are both representatives of "the Machine". It 
nullifies space and time. It is also a deceit, because there is really no 
more space and time to be ruled when they are brought to zero. (Of course I 
do not try to say that ALL train traveling is evil, but I hope you get my 
point).

In these days the example of these kind of aspirations is transhumanism. 
Sometimes I think that if people really become inpatient enough, could it 
and up that some might plug themselves into machines that give them the 
stimuli they want right when the desire is born, be it sensual, visual, 
auditive or some other kind of desire. Then those people would just float 
in the utter annihilation of space and time and any human effort or 
development of human person or virtues. In the book the ultimate machine is 
the One Ring. It is made by Sauron to coerce the material world and other 
will and minds. That is why it must be destroyed. If Gandalf or Aragorn 
used the Ring, they would end up forcing the world and other people to 
agree with them "for their own good".
comments.author: sakor88

comments.text:
+sakor88 I see, but why can't the eagles fly the hobbits NEAR Mordor? would 
save a lot of trouble...
comments.author: Tom Gross

comments.text:
+Tom Gross One Ring gave power over other minds and wills, whether those 
persons wore Rings of Power or not. Besides, Sauron gave the other rings to 
Men and Dwarves, so they took them as gifts.

During the War of the Ring (the conflict that takes place in the Lord of 
the Rings book) Sauron did not need the One Ring to win. He had plotted for 
three thousand years and Gondor, although relatively strong, was no match 
to all the realm subject to Sauron. Sauron also had his physical body 
formed, he did not need the One Ring to that.

Sauron wanted to have the One Ring so that he could know what had been done 
with the Three Elven Rings during these three thousand years. These rings 
were linked into the One so that if Sauron got the One Ring back he would 
basically know all the plots and secrets of his greatest enemies (Elrond, 
Galadriel, Gandalf and Círdan). 

Sauron also wanted to get the Ring back because he did not want anyone else 
to use it against him. Unlike these videos assume, the Ring could have been 
used by others. Even Frodo could have used it to bend weaker persons to his 
will if he had such aspirations and had trained his mind to control, coerce 
and dominate other persons. Some other persons like Gandalf, Galadriel or 
Elrond could have used the Ring effectively against Sauron, provided they 
had enough time to learn how to master the Ring. And Aragorn could have 
used the Ring against Sauron. When Aragorn reveals himself to Sauron in the 
Helm's Deep via the palantir and wrestles the palantir away from Sauron's 
control, Sauron is terrified since he thinks that now Aragorn has the Ring. 
That is why he is too hasty and launches his invasion before he is ready 
and orders his armies to try to storm Minas Tirith instead of starting a 
long siege.

And Eagles could not have carried the Hobbits to the Sammath Naur where the 
Ring was forged. If anyone had noticed the approaching Great Eagles, then I 
assume that Sauron could have just ordered few hundred archers near the 
Door of Sammath Naur and the plan would have been foiled. And Gandalf did 
not mean Eagles. "Fly" is synonymous with "flee" here.

comments.text:
+sakor88 Since, I read you reply I went check a few argument from both 
sides and I found out that you were right. Most of argument about Tolkien 
being racist were kind of weak and or at least debatable while the argument 
from the other side were well based and just more serious. 

I won't have this misconception anymore. And the history about Mongols and 
Arabs equally interesting.


So, thank you for your clarification.
comments.author: Maximiliano Villarroel

comments.text:
+Maximiliano Villarroel Tolkien despised racial theories of nazis and did 
not like apartheid politics of South-Africa. Orcs are just orcs. The 
stories are written from a European perspective, and considering how Europe 
was attacked from east by Mongols and from south and south-east by Arabs 
during the Middle-ages then I guess it is understandable that a story that 
takes much of its inspiration from medieval literature might consider 
certain peoples as enemies.

And white númenoreans of the Second Age became evil imperialists that 
established colonies in Middle-earth and oppressed native peoples of 
different ethnic backround... and they were punished for it and their 
homeland sank beneath the sea.

But it is certainly correct that the book would not be considered as 
politically correct if it were written these days.

comments.author: Zanfib32

comments.text:
+Zanfib32 They cannot be turned into wraiths and are especially resistant 
to outside oppression, but they still would want to use the Ring. People 
who made this video really do not understand the story. Ring COULD be used 
by many, even by Frodo (if he practiced his mind to oppress and dominate 
other minds and wills). People like Elrond, Galadriel, Gandalf and Aragorn 
would even have been able to use it effectively against Sauron. That is 
what Sauron feared. It seems that this video build upon the foundation of 
lore which has been diluted by Jackson's movies, where "you cannot use the 
Ring since it obeys only Sauron alone". That is simply not true.

Even Frodo wanted to use the Ring, but he was considered to be the best (or 
least poor) option to carry the Ring.

comments.text:
Huh, I thought there was more to it. What I got from the books was that the 
Ring focused whatever natural abilities someone had. It made hobbits 
invisible because (as the books say) they were already exceptionally good 
at not being seen when they didn't want to be. Gandalf and Galadriel 
presumably weren't tempted by invisibility, but by power of the sort they 
already wielded and craved to extend.﻿
comments.author: Gabriel Bodeen

comments.text:
+Gabriel Bodeen No. The Ring made the wearer to walk in the Unseen. Since 
Sauron was a Maia-spirit he already walked in Unseen AND Seen. Men (and 
Hobbits, who are practically a "subrace" of Men) walk only in the Seen. 
That is the reason why the Ring makes them invisible.

The Ring gives its wearer a greater power over physical world and other 
minds and wills. It is a "Machine"... apparatus that makes your desires to 
come true with much less effort. Gandalf, Elrond, Galadriel or Aragorn 
could have used the Ring against Sauron effectively, perhaps even Denethor 
(although I am not so sure about that). That is the reason why Sauron is 
hasty... first he sees Pippin in the Seeing-stone and assumes that he is 
the Halfling that had the Ring and that therefore Saruman has the Ring. 
Next he sees Aragorn in the Seeing-stone when Aragorn uses it in Helm's 
Deep after they return from Isengard. Sauron learns that Heir of Isildur is 
alive and assumes that Aragorn has the Ring. Because it would take time to 
learn to wield the Ring, Sauron hurries in order to push all his enemies 
into the Sea before Aragorn learns how to use the Ring.

CGP Grey, You made one mistake, so I have one correction to make: it IS 
possible for a being to use the One Ring to overthrow Sauron, but there are 
firstly very few individuals strong enough to do so, and second, that 
individual would be inevitably corrupted to the point where you would 
essentially have another evil being replacing Sauron.

In my mind, i can think that Celeborn, Galadriel, and Gandalf are probably 
3 of the few beings who are powerful enough to overthrow and replace Sauron 
in this way. Of course, they never would, for they are too wise to use 
attempt to use the One Ring.﻿

comments.author: Gergely Pintér

comments.text:
In some of his letters, Tolkien said that Bombadil represents something or 
someone who is interested about things "in themselves", not how they are 
related to him. Therefore he is not tempted by the Ring, since he does not 
simply care.

We know that he is not God (Eru). We can be fairly certain that he is not 
Ainu (Vala or Maia = an angel, although it is possible that he is a Maia). 
It is suggested that he was in the World before Ainur arrived, and that 
would make him "the Eldest" since although Ainur existed "before" the 
world, they were outside of time and and arrived to the World AFTER it was 
created.

But... we can only make educated guesses and rule out certain things, such 
as he is not God, he is not Manwe or any other of the Valar. I myself enjoy 
the fact that we do not know everything about Tolkien's world. To explain 
everything would take away the spell. Everything does not just fall into 
neat and handy categories for our convenience.

Although... this video has some misconceptions... :/ Possibly they have 
their origins in movie adaptations.

Sauron is the Lord of the Rings. One can attempt to become a new Ringlord 
by trying to use the Ring against Sauron. Aragorn, Gandalf, Galadriel and

But in the end the one who had overthrown Sauron would only become a new 
Dark Lord.

comments.text:
And yet this video misunderstood the crux of the issue. Ring could be used 
against Sauron and even successfully. In the long run that path would have 
only replaced one Dark Lord with another, however. The problem is not that 
only Sauron can use the Ring (this is not correct), the problem is that it 
is not right to use such power to coerce other will and minds, even for 
"their own good".

comments.author: Mike Hunt

comments.text:
The rings seems to enhance the native power of the user and also give the 
user something of their own nature. 

Cirdan gave Gandalf Nenya, the right of fire, and Gandalf quickly became 
known for his fireworks and fire magic. Celembrimbor gave Galadriel the 
ring of water, and we note her connection to her "seeing pool" in 
Lothlorien. I can't remember if we're told the larticular affinity of the 
ring given to Elrond, but I wouldn't be surprised if Rivendell bears some 
mark associated with that Ring's "personality".

So, give a ring to a warrior and they become an unstoppable juggernaut. 
Give it to Legolas and he becomes an arrow gatling gun. Give it to a sneaky 
hobbit and he becomes super sneaky. Give it to Sam and he becomes super 
brave. 

But I suspect that over time the user's mastery of a ring deepens and the 
benefits become more subtle and profound - they become a kind of idealism, 
greater version of themselves. The Lord of the Nazgul becomes more than 
just a fearsome warrior but a great general and commander. Elrond becomes 
wise and far seeing. Galadriel becomes so ethereal she begins to seem more 
like a Maia than an Elf. Gandalf becomes wise and self-effacing, with an 
ability to see the big picture that dwarfs even Elrond and Galadriel. 
Gollum became a monster in part because thats the particularly evil natute 
of the One, but also because, at bottom, that's who he was - a jealous 
cousin-murdering petty cutthroat. 

One of the things I like about the Shadow of Mordor game is how it portrays 
the way the One influenced Celebrimbor - he became a shining, beautiful, 
graceful figure, bent for originally righteous reasons on vengeance and 
domination. "Bright Lord" indeed. And the way Talion is similarly corrupted 
seems to me to be part of this too...﻿
comments.author: Benjamin O'Donnell

comments.text:
+Benjamin O'Donnell No, it does not fit to the source material since Mordor 
was under the rule of the Ringwraiths and dead men do not come back alive 
and because Celebrimbor never used the One Ring and never massed an army of 
orcs against Sauron.
comments.author: sakor88

comments.text:
I think you're missing my point about how the Shadow of Mordor can "fit" 
into the official story as a lost chapter - a chapter unknown to elves & 
men, in part because it mostly happened in Mordor as a war between orcs, 
and in part because it wasn't a very edifying incident that the Elves would 
want widely known.
comments.author: Benjamin O'Donnell

comments.text:
+Benjamin O'Donnell Sauron did torture him so that he would reveal the 
location of the rings, but he did not reveal the location of the three. 
Celebrimbor's body was hung upon a pole and pierced with arrows and used as 
a banner when the armies of Sauron attacked against Lindon. Celebrimbor 
never stole the Ring and never massed an army of orcs against Sauron. When 
Sauron returned to Mordor in the Third Age there was no Gondorian garrison 
at the Black Gate and Mordor was already under his control since it was 
ruled by the Ringwraiths who were in Minas Morgul. Disembodied elven spirit 
cannot resurrect a dead human... and actually no power in the world can do 
that. Shadow of Mordor is not compatible with the source material.
comments.author: sakor88

comments.text:
It doesn't contradict the source material. We know Sauron captured 
Celebrimbor. We suspect he took him back to Morder.  We know the Ring is 
treacherous...
